In our previous study, we introduced a heterogeneous catalyst, denoted as H5[PMo11MnO39(H2O)]0.30@ [Fe3O(OH)(H2O)2[C6H3(CO2)3]2·8H2O (C1), through the encapsulation of a homogeneous polyoxometalate, H5[PMo11Mn(H2O)O39] (MnP), within a metal–organic framework [Fe3O(OH)(H2O)2[C6H3(CO2)3]2·14H2O (MIL-100-Fe). In the present study, we utilized the same catalyst for the oxidation of cyclohexene (CyH), cis-cyclooctene (CyO), styrene (Sty), and geraniol (Ger) in acetonitrile, employing H2O2 as a green oxidant. Kinetic studies were carried out to investigate the influence of substrate, H2O2, catalyst concentration, reaction time, temperature, and total H2O2 decompositions on oxidation and selectivity. C1 exhibited significantly higher efficiency in catalyzing the allylic oxidation of all substrates compared to individual components MnP and MIL-100-Fe, in terms of conversion percentage, rate constants, turnover numbers (TONs), H2O2 efficiencies, and product selectivity. Under optimized conditions, C1 achieved overall conversions of 85 %, 96 %, 98 %, and 100 % for CyH, CyO, Sty, and Ger, respectively. The harmonious catalytic function of polyoxometalates (POM) and metal-organic frameworks (MOF) in C1 also reduced the auto-decomposition of H₂O₂ which resulted into higher H2O2 efficiencies. Notably, the catalyst exhibited complete recoverability and reusability without any structural changes or loss of activity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Polyoxometalates Metal organic frameworks Organic-inorganic hybrid composites; Olefin conversions Gas chromatography Kinetic studies Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The catalytic oxidation of organic compounds serves the purpose of generating oxygenated derivatives, which are highly valued as versatile commercial intermediates, facilitating subsequent reactions to yield essential materials [1]. In contemporary research and industrial practice, the principles of green and sustainable chemistry exert profound influence. Aqueous hydrogen peroxide stands out as a particularly attractive oxidant, owing to its favorable environmental and economic attributes. Consequently, it triggers to identify and employ efficient catalysts capable of activating hydrogen peroxide, given the significant waste generated by conventional oxidants such as manganese dioxide, chromic acid, potassium dichromate, or selenium dioxide, especially when applied on an industrial scale [2]. In recent literature, various catalysts for the oxidation of olefins have emerged, including expanded graphite-supported copper catalyst [3]. Fe–Co doped graphitic carbon nitride, and supported metal complex catalyst [4-6]. While many of these complexes have demonstrated promising activity in alkene epoxidation, they are often hindered by significant drawbacks in practical applications. Notably, a substantial excess of H2O2 (8–10 equiv. relative to substrate) was typically required, attributed to extensive H2O2 disproportionation during a pre-reaction phase preceding organic substrate oxidation. Additionally, these catalyst systems exhibited activity solely in ketone-based solvents like acetone, posing additional risks in H2O2-mediated oxidations [7]. Despite some notable advancements, the quest for more stable and efficient catalysts remains ongoing [6]. Polyoxometalates (POMs) represent discrete anionic metal-oxygen clusters that have garnered significant attention due to their fascinating properties, including oxidative stability, adjustable oxidation states, and the ability to activate various oxidants and exhibit inherent acidity [8]. POMs are commonly recognized as soluble alternates of metal oxides, and they have exhibited extensive effectiveness in both oxidative and acid catalysis across homogeneous and heterogeneous systems. Offering diverse structures and reversible redox properties without suffering from structural changes, POMs have been expansively explored for organic transformation reactions [9,10]. Among these, H5[PMo11Mn(H2O)O39] (MnP) stands out as a prominent POM for the oxidation reactions of alkenes, demonstrating superior efficiency compared to many others. Its cesium and tetrabutyl salts have been employed in heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysis, respectively [2]. However, prior studies have highlighted that similar to other POMs, MnP faces limitations such as low specific surface area, poor stability under catalytic conditions, and problematic separation from solvent after a catalytic reaction [11]. One of the most effective approaches to rule out all limitations involves encapsulation of POM within metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a novel class of crystalline coordination polymers known for their porous nature, high surface areas, and tunable cavities serving as excellent carriers [12-14]. This integration of POM and MOFs, termed PMOFs, effectively addresses difficulties associated with POMs, promotes the stability and enhances the catalytic activity of both components through a mutual synergic effect caused by electrostatic interaction between them [15]. In addition to their applications in photochemical/electrochemical water splitting [16,17], Li-ion batteries [18], detection of certain chemicals, oxidative desulphurization [19], p-nitrophenol reduction [20], removal of dyes [21], photoluminescence [22], nitrogen reduction reaction [23], PMOFs have demonstrated activity in numerous organic transformation reactions as catalysts [24]. Numerous researchers have widely used MIL-101 for encapsulating POMs owing to its high surface area and straightforward synthetic protocols. However, it is plagued by a significant issue of leaching, reaching up to 47 % in certain instances due to the larger openings of its cavities compared to POMs [25]. In recent years, MIL-100-Fe ([Fe3O(OH)(H2O)2[C6H3(CO2)3]2·14H2O) has emerged as a notable Lewis acid catalyst, demonstrating exceptional performance in organic synthesis [26,27]. The 3D crystalline iron(III) trimesate, MIL-100-Fe, features two distinct sets of mesoporous cages, with diameters measuring 25 Å and 29 Å, along with windows of 5.5 Å and 8.6 Å, respectively. Notably, it boasts a surface area of 2800 m²/g [16]. The Lewis acid sites could be created by removal of coordinated OH⁻ or F⁻ anions from the iron octahedral structure [28]. Previously we embedded MnP in MIL-100-Fe and yielded excellent results for the reduction of p-nitrophenol [20]. In this study, we utilize the same pre-synthesized and characterized catalyst, denoted as MnP@MIL-100-Fe (C1), for the oxidation of CyH, CyO, Sty, and Ger. Our results demonstrate that C1 represents a non-leachable catalyst assembly characterized by improved stability, enhanced activity, higher surface area, and complete recovery from the solvent. Importantly, C1 maintains its catalytic activity in subsequent experiments without conglomeration. In olefin oxidation with H2O2, vital factors include H2O2 activation and efficiency, olefin conversion, and product selectivity. Encapsulating POMs in MOFs enhances these aspects by promoting the formation of POM-OOH species, a critical step in the oxidation reaction, which can be facilitated by boosting the intrinsic catalytic activity of POMs, particularly their Lewis acid strength. The stability of the POM-OOH species can be enhanced through hydrogen bonding with hydrogen bond acceptors present in the reaction system [29]. The efficiency of oxygen atom utilization is defined as the ratio of product to consumed H2O2. However, complete utilization of H2O2 is often hindered by its undesired decomposition [30]. The efficiency of H2O2 utilization is primarily determined by the competition between its oxidation and decomposition pathways, which is further influenced by the interaction of olefin with the Lewis acid catalyst. Additionally, hydrophobicity indirectly impacts H2O2 efficiency. Hydrophobic surfaces tend to attract and become enriched with organic substrates, facilitating the transfer of active oxygen atoms to reactants, thereby reducing undesired decomposition and increasing H2O2 utilization efficiency [31]. Heterogenization of POMs in MOFs increases the electrophilicity of POMs by transferring electronic density from POMs to MOFs, enhancing the interaction between them and promoting the formation and stability of POM-OOH [32]. In C1, the O-atoms of POM-OOH specie are more electrophilic than in homogeneous POMs, resulting in a stronger interaction between POM-OOH and olefins. This reduces H2O2 decomposition and enhances its efficiency. Additionally, encapsulation of POMs in MOFs enriches the organic substrate at the surface due to the hydrophobic nature of MOFs, enhancing the interaction between the substrate and active species [33]. Encapsulation not only resolves these issues but also allows for the optimization of reaction conditions, including the amount of substrate, catalyst, and H2O2, as well as reaction time and temperature, to achieve high selectivity for a specific product [34]. 2 Experimental The original paper where we first introduced the catalyst provides a comprehensive description of all synthetic protocols [20]. Additionally, detailed information regarding characterization methods and instrumentation can be found in the Supporting Information (S1). 2.1 Oxidation reaction and kinetic studies The oxidation reactions of CyH, CyO, Sty, and Ger were conducted in acetonitrile within a closed 5 mL reaction vessel, fitted with a reflux condenser and equipped with a magnetic stirrer. H2O2 (30 wt.% aqueous solution) served as the oxidant. Reaction temperatures for CyH, CyO, and Sty ranged from 40 to 80 °C, while reactions involving Ger were carried out at room temperature in dark. Following the reaction, the mixture was centrifuged to separate the catalyst, and the organic phase was analyzed using a GC/MS instrument (Shimadzu GC 2014). Quantification was performed using a gas chromatograph with toluene as the internal standard [6]. 2.2 H2O2 decomposition studies The auto decomposition of H2O2 and the decomposition at the surface of catalyst were measured by iodometric titration. A round-bottom flask containing 3 mL of MeCN, and 140 µL of 30 % H2O2 was heated and stirred at 60 °C for 6 h. For the iodometric titration, the solution was filtered into a 150 mL Erlenmeyer flask, and 40 mL of acetic acid:chloroform (2:1) and 30 mL of saturated solution of aqueous KI were added. After stirring in darkness for 1 hour, 60 mL of H2O were added, and the solution was titrated with 0.1 M aqueous Na2S2O3 [35]. For auto decomposition, I2 produced from the reaction between H2O2 and I −(from KI) was titrated against 0.1 M aqueous Na2S2O3. For decomposition at the surface of catalyst, 15 mg of C1 were also added in the reaction mixture the H2O2 concentration was measured in a similar way. The efficiency of H2O2 consumption was calculated from the total consumption of H2O2 using the following formula [36]. H 2 O 2 efficiency ( % ) = moles of product moles of H 2 O 2 consumed × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations To ensure the integrity of the pre-synthesized and stored catalyst, detailed characterizations were performed. Briefly, Fig. 1a and 1b depict the PXRD patterns and FTIR spectrum of composite C1, respectively. The PXRD pattern of the composite corresponds well with the simulated pattern of MIL-100-Fe, indicating the structural integrity. The presence of absorption peaks of MnP alongside those of MIL-100-Fe in the FTIR spectrum confirms their presence in the composite. Furthermore, their absence in the PXRD pattern indicates their encapsulation within the MOFs, rather than mere adsorption on the surfaces [37]. Since the MnP units are irregularly distributed within the pores of the MOFs, they do not exhibit diffraction, explaining the absence of their peaks in the PXRD of the PMOFs composite [38]. The slight shifting of MnP peaks in the spectra of C1 is attributed to electrostatic interactions between its components [39]. Additionally, the PXRD results suggest the absence of impurities in the composite material. In thermogravimetric analysis shown in Fig. 1c, the first and second weight losses correspond to the removal of water molecules and the collapsing of organic ligands, respectively. It is evident that C1 exhibits relatively lower weight losses, i.e., 20 % and 33 %, compared to MOFs, which shows 28 % and 48 % in these two steps, respectively. This difference can be attributed to the accommodation of POM units in C1. Furthermore, the second weight loss step in C1 occurs at a higher temperature range, i.e., 350–400 °C, compared to MOFs, which is at 320–350 °C, suggesting the higher thermal stability of C1 than MIL-100-Fe. Elemental analysis in Table S1 confirms the presence of all elements of POM in the composite and evaluates the exact percentage of MnP in MIL-100-Fe. These results suggest a total loading of 30 wt.% of MnP in MIL-100-Fe. The combined results of TGA and elemental analyses propose the formula Fe3O(OH)(H2O)2[C6H3(CO2)3]2·14H2O for MIL-100-Fe, which is in agreement with previous reports, and [Fe3O(OH)(H2O)2[C6H3(CO2)3]2][PMo11MnO39(H2O)]0.30·8H2O for C1, calculated using an already reported method [39]. The number of acidic protons was determined through acid-base titration and back-titration [32]. NaOH solution was used to neutralize the acidic protons of heteropolyanions through diffusion of hydroxide ions into the frameworks. After filtration, the filtrate was back titrated through HCl to calculate the residual hydroxide ions after neutralization. This experiment allowed the calculation of acidic protons in C1. Same procedure was adopted to measure the acidity of pure MIL-100-Fe in order to compare and correct the calculated acidity of C1. Results indicated that 1 mole of C1 contains 1.43 mol of acidic protons which corresponds to 4.7 ≈ 5 protons per MnP unit in C1. From the data of nitrogen adsorption isotherms in Fig. 1d, the values of pore volume and Langmuir surface area of MIL-100-Fe were found to be 0.881 cm3⋅g −1 and 2800 m2⋅g −1, respectively, which are in agreement with previous reports [39]. These values for C1 have been reduced to 0.325 cm3⋅g −1 and 1030 m2⋅g −1, respectively. This behavior is attributed to the existence of POM units inside the pores of the MOF. Furthermore, these results reveal that there is still residual porosity in C1 despite the accommodation of POM units, which is imperative in catalysis for the diffusion of reactants [6]. Fig. 2 displays XPS analysis, consistent with previous reports [20]. In Fig. 2a, binding energies at 712.1 eV and 726.0 eV are characteristic of the 2p spectrum of Fe3+. In 2b, two peaks at 284 eV and 289 eV are due to phenyl and carboxyl groups, respectively, while the peak appearing at 285 eV has been attributed to surface carbon. Fig. 2c shows binding energies at 641.3 eV and 653.8 eV, attributed to Mn2+. The doublet in 2d, with binding energies of 232.2 eV and 235.6 eV, confirms the existence of Mo6+. A single peak at 133.9 eV in 2e is due to phosphorus. A doublet at 531 eV and 532 eV in 2f has been assigned to oxygen components. The presence of Mo, Mn, and P confirms the presence of POM units inside the cavities of MOFs. 3.2 Catalytic performance and kinetic studies The catalytic performance of C1 was assessed in the oxidation of various olefins under different conditions to optimize its activity. To establish the impact of immobilization, oxidation reactions were also conducted without a catalyst and with individual MnP and MIL-100-Fe. Table 1 , and Fig. 3 and S1 provide a summary of all the results obtained. The reaction kinetics of substrates with aqueous H2O2 were investigated in liquid-phase batch reactions with periodic sampling. Factors such as catalyst and substrate concentrations, H2O2-to-substrate ratio, optimal reaction time and temperature, and H2O2 decomposition effects on the oxidation rate were studied. Cyclohexene (CyH), epoxide (1a), 2-cyclohexene-1-ol (2a), CyH-1-one (3a) and 1,2-cyclohexane diol (4a), 2-hydroxyy Cyclohexanone (5a), Iso-cyclooctene (CyO), epoxide (1b), Styrene (Sty), benzaldehyde (1c), phenyl acetyl aldehyde (2c), acetophenone (3c), benzoic acid (4c), 2‑hydroxy-1-phenyl acetone (5c), epoxide (6c), Geraniol (Ger), epoxide (1d), diepoxide (2d). 3.2.1 H2O2 decomposition studies H2O2 undergoes decomposition to produce O2 and H2O at higher temperatures and at surface of various transition metals i.e., V, Ti, Mn, Fe, Cu etc. [30]. Hence, it is crucial to evaluate the background level of H2O2 decomposition caused by C1. Table 2 displays the extent of H2O2 decomposition under specified reaction conditions after 6 h at various temperatures, as assessed by iodometric titration. The results indicate that, in the absence of solids, H2O2 decomposition is insignificant even at elevated temperatures. However, the decomposition rate increases significantly when individual components of the composite, MIL-100-Fe and MnP, are used. Furthermore, the decomposition rate is enhanced when a physical mixture of both components is employed. In contrast, the use of C1 substantially decreases H2O2 decomposition at all temperatures (Fig. 4a ). This is not surprising as PMOFs often exhibit superior performance compared to their individual constituents due to their electrostatic interactions [25]. A plot of 1/[H2O2] versus time yields a straight line with a slope of 0.9 at various temperatures, suggesting a second-order dependence on H2O2 (Fig. 4b). The H2O2 decomposition data is fitted to a kinetic expression (Eq. (1)) that is second-order in H2O2 and first-order in C1, based on the catalytic reaction 2H2O2 → 2H2O + O2 on C1 sites. Previous studies have assessed multi-order dependence on H2O2 in the case of alkene epoxidation [40]. The inhibitory effects of water were also investigated, showing no significant impact on H2O2 decomposition. (1) r d e c o m = − d H 2 O 2 d t = r d e c o m [ C 1 ] [ H 2 O 2 ] 2 3.3 Conversion and kinetic profile of cyclohexene (CyH) Table 1 and figure 3a depict the epoxidation of CyH by C1 and its components. Without a catalyst, there was negligible conversion over a 9-hour period at 80 °C. MIL-100-Fe catalyzed the oxidation of CyH with only 19 % conversion, yielding 2-cyclohexene-1-ol (2a), CyH-1-one (3a), and 1,2-cyclohexane diol (4a) with selectivity of 11 %, 58 %, and 31 %, respectively, after 9 h at 80 °C. In contrast, the oxidation of CyH with MnP resulted in 61 % conversion after 6 h, producing epoxide (1a), 2a, 3a, 4a, and 2-hydroxycyclohexanone (5a) with selectivity of 9 %, 13 %, 29 %, 41 %, and 8 %, respectively. Significantly improved CyH conversion of 85 % with 100 % epoxide selectivity was achieved at a reduced temperature of 70 °C in the case of the C1. Conversion continued to increase over six hours, but H2O2 efficiencies decreased; thus, six hours was considered the optimal time. The heterogenization of MnP in MIL-100-Fe not only enhanced conversion rates but also greatly influenced the product distribution. While MIL-100-Fe favored the production of 2-cyclohexen-1-one, C1 favored epoxide production. Such variations in product distribution of hybrids compared to their individual components have been previously reported. This enhancement in activity can be attributed to the MIL-100 scaffold with its high surface area, better stability, and non-leachable assembly for the POM [6]. To determine the best results and kinetic parameters and propose a mechanism, various factors affecting the epoxidation of CyH were studied (table S2) [6,35]. The impact of reaction time on CyH conversion and epoxide production at 70 °C is detailed in Fig. 5a . Extending the reaction time from 3 to 8 h led to a notable increase in CyH conversion from 51 % to 91 %. After six hours, there was no further increase in epoxide formation, instead a decrease in epoxidation rates (-(∂[CyH]/∂t)) was observed. This decrease could be attributed to several aspects, including depletion of CyH with time, accelerated consumption of H2O2 by auto decomposition, inhibition in rate due to the binding of Lewis basic H2O, and epoxide produced at the C1 center, or to poisons by some co-products [41,42]. The H2O2 efficiency peaked at 87 % after 6 h but declined slightly afterward. Based on the pursuit of the best rates of epoxidation, maximum H2O2 efficiency, and 827 TONs, 6 h emerged as the preferred reaction time, achieving 85 % conversion of CyH. A plot of ln[CyH] versus time in Fig. 5b produces a straight line, with its slope giving the value of the rate constant k as 3.13 × 10−1[36]. Epoxidation was found to increase with the increase in the amount of catalyst from 5 mg to 25 mg (Fig. 5c). The H2O2 efficiencies increased up to 15 mg of C1 and then started to decrease beyond this value. Hence, 15 mg of catalyst, which provided 91 % conversion of CyH, the highest TONs, and 87 % H2O2 efficiency, was employed in further experiments. The initial rate of formation of epoxide varied approximately linearly with respect to C1 amounts over the experimental range, indicating a first-order dependence of the reaction on C1 amounts. This was verified through a plot of ln[epoxide] versus ln[C1], which produced a straight line with a slope of 0.8. Similarly, the rates of epoxidation increased by varying the amount of CyH, reaching their highest values and then decreasing afterward under given conditions. A plot of ln[epoxide] versus ln[CyH] produced a straight line with a slope of 1.2, suggesting almost a first-order rate dependence on CyH concentration (Fig. 5d). Applying a range of H2O2:CyH ratios from 1:1 to 3:1, it was evident that with the increasing quantity of H2O2, the epoxidation of CyH also increased. Specifically, as the molar ratio of H2O2/CyH rose from 1:1 to 2:1, the epoxidation of CyH augmented to 94 %, with the best TONS and H2O2 efficiencies. Beyond this ratio, there was a decline in rates and in H2O2 efficiencies. Consequently, based on these findings, a molar ratio of 2:1 was selected as the best ratio for the epoxidation of CyH on C1 surfaces. A plot of ln[epoxide] versus ln[H2O2] in Fig. 5e produced a straight line with a slope of 0.8 for C1, suggesting a limiting first-order rate dependence on H2O2 concentration. Finally, the effects of temperature were investigated, as shown in Fig. 5f. It's clear that higher temperatures led to improvements in CyH epoxidation, H2O2 efficiency, and TONs. Notably, at 70 °C, a CyH conversion of 85 % with 827 TONs and an H2O2 efficiency of 84 % were achieved. However, beyond this temperature, there was a slight decrease in epoxide concentration, likely due to its conversion into other products not further examined [43]. Therefore, 70 °C was determined to be the optimal temperature. Epoxidation reactions and kinetic studies for CyO, Ger, and Sty were conducted following the same procedure as for CyH, as outlined briefly below. 3.4 Conversion and kinetic profile of cyclooctene (CyO) The oxidation of CyO was investigated using C1 and its individual components with H2O2 as the oxidant (table 1 and figure 3b). Varied conversion rates were observed in all cases, but the selectivity for the epoxide remained consistently at 100 %. Initially, the reaction was conducted without any catalyst, yielding only a 7 % conversion of CyO to its corresponding epoxide after 9 h at 80 °C. When MIL-100-Fe was utilized as a catalyst under the same conditions, the product and selectivity remained consistent, resulting in a 14 % conversion. The use of MnP as a homogeneous catalyst increased the conversion to 63 % in 7 h with 413 TONs. However, employing catalyst C1 led to a significant enhancement, achieving a conversion of 96 % in just 7 h at a reduced temperature of 70 °C, with 728 TONs. The epoxidation of CyO with H2O2 typically follows a concerted mechanism, wherein a cyclic transition state is formed as the hydrogen peroxide molecule adds to the double bond, resulting in the formation of an oxirane ring (epoxide) and cleavage of the OO bond in hydrogen peroxide. The stereochemistry of the product is determined by the starting alkene [44]. CyO oxide is known to be one of the most stable epoxides due to the steric hindrance of the cis-cyclooctane ring, retarding every reaction of the epoxide group [45]. Hence, the conversion of CyO into its epoxide reaches up to 100 % [46]. Table S3 outlines the experiments during optimization process to determine the conditions for maximum activity. The impact of reaction time on CyO conversion at 70 °C is illustrated in Figure S2a and S2b. Extending the reaction time from 3 h to 8 h resulted in a significant increase in CyO conversion and H2O2 efficiencies, reaching 96 % and 81 % respectively, with 728 TONs. Beyond the 7 h mark, there was a decrease in H2O2 efficiencies, and no further increase in epoxide concentration was observed. A plot of ln[CyO] versus time yielded a straight line with a rate constant value of - 4.6 × 10−1. Figure S2c demonstrate that varying the amounts of C1 from 5 mg to 17.5 mg resulted in CyO conversions, H2O2 efficiencies, and TONs reaching 96 %, 81 %, and 728 respectively before starting to decrease. A plot of ln[epoxide] versus ln[C1] yielded a straight line with a slope of 0.7, indicating a first-order reaction with respect to C1. The initial rate of CyO epoxidation, as shown in Figure S2d, also displayed a linear relationship with the concentration of CyO. A plot of ln[epoxide] versus ln[CyO] yielded a straight line with a slope of 1.3, suggesting an almost first-order dependence on CyO concentration. Figure S2e reveal that an increase in the quantity of H2O2 led to an increase in CyO conversion, reaching a maximum of 96 % for an H2O2/CyO molar ratio of 2:1 before declining. A plot of ln[epoxide] versus ln[H2O2] resulted in a straight line with a slope of 0.9, indicating a limiting first-order rate dependence on H2O2 concentration. The impact of reaction temperature on CyO conversion is outlined in Figure S2f. Higher temperatures resulted in increased CyO conversion, H2O2 efficiency, epoxidation, and TONs. Notably, the highest values for these parameters, 96 % for epoxidation, and 81 % for H2O2 efficiency, were achieved at 70 °C. 3.5 Conversion and kinetic profile of styrene (Sty) Terminal epoxides are generally resistant to oxidation, but Sty oxide shows high reactivity due to the electronic influence of the aromatic ring [45]. As a result, it acts as an intermediate during the oxidation of Sty and is quickly converted to benzaldehyde (benz) (1c) after its formation. Sty tends to oxidize to 1c via the cleavage of the vinylic double bond [47]. Table 1 shows that in the absence of a catalyst, there was no reaction observed over a prolonged period of 9 h. MIL-100-Fe alone exhibited a 45.6 % conversion of Styrene to 1c with a selectivity of 53 % and 280 TONs, along with the corresponding epoxide (6c) (27 %) and other minor products (20 %), including phenylacetyl aldehyde (2c), acetophenone (3c), benzoic acid (4c), and 2‑hydroxy-1-phenylethanol (5c). Similar levels of Sty conversion have been reported previously with MIL-100-Fe and other MOFs [48]. Using MnP, a 75 % yield of benzaldehyde was achieved with 260 TONs, accompanied by minor by-products. However, with C1, the selectivity for benzaldehyde reached 100 %, achieving a 98 % conversion rate with TONs of 1144 (fig. 3c). Previous studies have demonstrated that PMOFs have been employed for the oxidation of styrene, yielding comparable results [48]. The conversion profile for Sty mirrors those of CyO and CyH, achieving nearly identical conversions after 6 h. Incorporating MnP into MIL-100-Fe not only enhances selectivity and conversion efficiency but also improves kinetics. Unlike the slow kinetics observed with MnP, the use of C1 demonstrated efficient kinetics in the oxidation of Sty. Furthermore, compared to other MOFs-based catalysts, ours induces conversion at relatively lower temperatures and in less time, with smaller quantities required [48]. Optimization of conditions for C1 was pursued to achieve optimal outcomes and shown in table S4. The impact of reaction time on the conversion of Sty at 60 °C is illustrated in figure S3a. Remarkably, extending the reaction time from 2 h to 12 h resulted in a substantial increase in styrene conversion, escalating from 35 % to 98 % within 6 h, accompanied by 1144 TONS. The efficiency of H2O2 peaked at 84 % after 6 h and showed a slight decline to 73 % thereafter. A plot of ln[Sty] versus time in figure S3b yields a straight line with a rate constant value of - 7.6 × 10−1. Figure S3c reveal that increasing the catalyst amount from 5 mg to 12.5 mg elevates the conversion of styrene to 98 %. However, beyond this point, the conversion decreases instead of further increasing. This could be attributed to the agglomeration of catalyst particles or the reverse reaction of products into reactants [6,49]. The H2O2 efficiencies also showed a decline thereafter. A plot of ln[benzaldehyde] versus ln[C1] produces a straight line with a slope of 0.7, indicating a first-order reaction with respect to C1. The initial rate of Sty, as depicted in figure S3d, also varies linearly with the concentration of Sty. A plot of ln[epoxide] versus ln[styrene] yields a straight line with a slope of 1.2, suggesting an almost first-order dependence on styrene concentration. The effect of H2O2 quantity on the oxidation of styrene, illustrated in figure S3e, demonstrates that as the molar ratio of H2O2/styrene increases to 2:1, the conversion of styrene rises from 49 % to 98 %. However, beyond this ratio, the conversion begins to decrease. A plot of ln[epoxide] versus ln[H2O2] yields a straight line with a slope of 0.8, indicating a limiting first-order rate dependence on H2O2 concentration. The impact of reaction temperature on the conversion of styrene is outlined in figure S3f. It is evident that increasing the temperature results in increases across styrene conversion, H2O2 efficiency, and TONs. Notably, the highest values for these parameters, 98 % for Sty conversion, 84 % for H2O2 efficiency, and 1144 TONs were achieved at 60 °C. It is noteworthy that catalyst C1 exhibited 100 % selectivity in converting styrene to benzaldehyde in all cases. 3.6 Conversion and kinetic profile of geraniol (Ger) Oxidizing Ger proves to be comparatively easier than other olefins examined in this study due to its multiple sites for oxidative attack [2]. Its kinetics also differ from those of other olefins. As table 1 shows, no oxidation reaction occurred without a catalyst. MIL-100-Fe alone demonstrated a 53 % conversion of Ger and 127 TONs in four hours, with corresponding epoxide (92 %) and diepoxide (8 %). With MnP, an 89 % conversion was achieved with 220 TONs in two hours, showing 95 % selectivity for the epoxide and 5 % for the diepoxide (refer to Table 1). However, when employing C1, as figure 3d exhibits, the selectivity for the epoxide reached 100 %, achieving a 100 % conversion rate with TONs of 2083. The efficiency of Ger conversion and its selectivity for the epoxide are not surprising, as similar efficiency has been reported using other PMOFs catalysts. The conversion profile for geraniol differs from the rest of the olefins used in this study, as its conversion reached 100 % in only 8 min. Immobilizing MnP in MIL-100-Fe not only enhances selectivity and conversion efficiency but also improves kinetics. Unlike the slow kinetics observed with individual MnP and MIL-100-Fe, the use of C1 demonstrated efficient kinetics in the oxidation of Ger. Moreover, the results demonstrated by C1 are comparable to those of other highly efficient PMOF-based catalysts [25,50,51]. The influence of various factors affecting the conversion of geraniol at 25 °C are presented in table S5. C1 achieved 100 % oxidation of Ger in only 8 min with 100 % selectivity for the epoxide and 2083 TONs (fig. S4a). The H2O2 efficiency peaked at 88 % within 8 min. A plot of ln[Ger] versus time in figure S4b produces a straight line with a rate constant value of - 6.1 × 10−1. Ger conversions shown in figure S4c also demonstrated increases as the amount of C1 rose from 1 mg to 7 mg. Beyond this point, the H2O2 efficiencies showed a decline. A plot of ln[epoxide] versus ln[C1], which produces a straight line with a slope of 1.2, roughly indicating a first-order reaction with respect to C1. The initial rate of geraniol conversion, given in figure S4d, also varies linearly by varying the concentration of geraniol. A plot of ln[epoxide] versus ln [Ger] produces a straight line with a slope of 1, suggesting a first-order dependence on geraniol concentration. The impact of H2O2 quantity on the oxidation of geraniol in figure S4e shows that as the molar ratio of H2O2/Ger increases to 2:1, the conversion of geraniol also increases, reaching 100 %. A plot of ln[epoxide] versus ln[H2O2] produces a straight line with a slope of 1, suggesting a limiting first-order rate dependence on H2O2 concentration. All the above experiments were conducted at room temperature, resulting in 100 % conversion and 2083 TONs, with 88 % efficiency of H2O2. Control experiments using physical mixtures of C1's components were also conducted i.e., homogeneous MnP and heterogeneous MIL-100-Fe. The results showed a consistent pattern in all cases: the mixtures performed similarly to homogeneous MnP alone, with identical selectivity and reduced conversion rates. The identical selectivity indicates that only MnP is active in this mixture, while MIL-100-Fe remains catalytically inactive. The reduced conversion is likely due to MIL-100-Fe interfering with the substrate-MnP interaction, as MIL-100-Fe can adsorb the substrate, leading to reduced conversion. 3.7 Suggested mechanism and explanation of heightened activity Based on our findings and previous research on similar systems, we propose the involvement of the following steps in the mechanism given in Scheme 1 (A and B) along with decomposition pathways of H2O2 (C). This mechanism involves the collaborative action of polyoxometalates (POMs) and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), with each component featuring a distinct active site, working together to facilitate a synergistic process. Initially, an aqua ligand is detached from the MnP i.e., Mn-H2O, creating a vacancy that is filled by H2O2 through the detachment of its proton. The alkene then interacts with this active species on MnP, Mn-O1O2H, where the O2-H bond of Mn-O1O2H is cleaved, and O is transferred to the alkene, producing the oxidized product and leaving behind Mn-OH. Finally, Mn-OH is protonated, completing the catalytic cycle with the formation of the original POM with intact Mn-H2O bond [52]. Concurrently, Fe-OH in MIL-100-Fe is protonated by the proton detached from H2O2 while attaching to Mn-OH, resulting in the formation of a Fe-H2O species [53]. It is known that Lewis's acid sites can be generated by removing the OH− or F − anions coordinated with the iron octahedral [28]. The aqua ligand detaches from the MOFs, followed by the attachment of H2O2 through the detachment of its proton [54]. This proton is accepted by Mn-OH in the last step of its catalytic cycle to regenerate the original species Mn-H2O. The resulting species Fe-O1O2H transfers its O-atom to the alkene, which approaches it, followed by the production of the original species Fe-OH and the completion of the catalytic cycle [55]. The composite, C1, outperforms its individual components significantly. Firstly, its superior conversion rates are attributed to the combined effects of MnP and MIL-100-Fe, which provide dual active surfaces to the substrates. These components complement each other, enhancing their activity synergistically. The proton loss from H2O2 during its attachment to Mn in POM is utilized to protonate Fe-OH in MOFs, initiating the catalytic cycle by generating Fe-H2O. Similarly, the proton produced from H2O2 while attaching to Fe in MOFs is used to protonate Mn-OH in POM, completing the catalytic cycle by generating Mn-H2O. This provides the substrate with two active centers for efficient oxidation. Secondly, the epoxidation of alkenes with H2O2 involves the activation of H2O2 and subsequent oxygen atom transfer [29]. The electrophilicity of the active center facilitates the dissociation of the O–O bond, promoting the reaction. Immobilizing POM in MOFs enhances their oxidation ability through electrostatic interactions [32]. The Mn-OOH formed in C1 is more electrophilic compared to that formed by naked MnP, as the excited electrons in MnP can be dissipated to MIL-100-Fe, enhancing the oxidative properties of MnP. Consequently, the oxidation of olefins is improved [17,49]. Thirdly, C1 facilitates the proximity of reactants for an effective reaction due to its higher surface area and porous adsorptive surface, acting as a microreactor. This allows the olefin molecule and oxygen atom to remain close enough for active insertion of the oxygen atom [49]. Fourthly, If the electrophilic oxygen atom in M-OOH could not insert into the double bond of the alkenes as soon as possible, it would be consumed by the surrounding H2O2 molecule to form water and oxygen [29]. The porous structure of C1 with a relatively higher surface area enhances the accessibility of substrate and oxidant molecules to active centers for a longer duration. This facilitates effective catalysis and fast diffusion of products, improving overall efficiency [49]. Fifthly, the high electrophilicity and oxidizing power of C1 contribute to higher efficiencies of H2O2 compared to individual MnP or MIL-100-Fe. MnP's electrophilicity and oxidizing power enhance the transfer of O-atom from activated H2O2 to olefin, reducing H2O2 decomposition. Sixthly, the high selectivity of C1 is attributed to the utilization and consumption of protons by Mn-OH and Fe-OH, protecting the acid-sensitive epoxide from ring opening [56]. The pore size of MOFs also plays a role in product selectivity. Smaller pore diameter of MIL-100-Fe may also protect allylic oxidation products from further oxidation [34]. Seventhly, the encapsulation of POM in MOFs makes them more resistant to hydrogen peroxide, allowing for a higher H2O2/alkene ratio and thus higher alkene conversion and epoxide selectivity compared to homogeneous conditions [57]. Eighthly, the hydrophobic nature of MIL-100-Fe allows organic substrates to easily approach and enrich at the surfaces of C1, enhancing the interaction between substrates and C1 compared to MnP alone, leading to heightened activity [29,33]. These improvements in POM activities after encapsulation in MOFs have been extensively reported previously [58,59]. 3.8 Recovery, stability and reusability of catalyst To investigate the reusability of the catalyst C1, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation after the first run, dried at 150 °C under vacuum and then recycled five times under the same conditions. Fig. 6 shows that it showed same activity in subsequent cycles and produced almost same results with minor variations as those of the fresh one. This intact activity is credited to non-leachable encapsulation of MnP in MIL-100-Fe, unlike MIL-101 whose cavities’ windows are bigger than the sizes of POM and it leads to leaching, causing a decrease in POM loading and results into lower activity. To confirm the loading percentage and stability of the structure, ICP (table S6), PXRD, FTIR, N2 adsorption studies (fig. S5), XPS (fig. S6) and TEM (fig. S7) analysis were carried out after the second cycle of catalysis. Figure S7 displays TEM images of composite C1, showcasing distorted square-shaped particles with sizes ranging from approximately 80 to 120 nanometers. Notably, the particles retain their size and shape before and after catalysis, indicating high stability and resistance to structural changes during the catalytic process. Additionally, TEM analysis of composite C1 indicates the absence of multiple particle types, suggesting that POM units are not merely present as a physical mixture but are encapsulated within the cavities of MIL-100-Fe. All of these results confirmed that catalyst remained unaffected after catalysis and is reusable. 4 Conclusion A hybrid material (denoted as C1) comprising polyoxometalate immobilized within MIL-100-Fe was employed as a catalyst to facilitate the oxidation of olefins. C1 exhibited significantly enhanced catalytic activities and stabilities in the challenging oxidation of CyH, CyO, Sty, and Ger using environmentally friendly H2O2 as the oxidant, compared to the individual components. This represents a remarkable achievement in the synthesis of POM/MOFs hybrids and the selective oxidation of olefins with high conversion rates. The catalyst demonstrated much higher activity than its constituent parts, and the reaction conditions could be fine-tuned to improve the selectivity of specific products. Furthermore, the catalyst proved to be 100 % recoverable, maintaining its stability and activity intact. coredata.dc:description: In our previous study, we introduced a heterogeneous catalyst, denoted as H5[PMo11MnO39(H2O)]0.30@ [Fe3O(OH)(H2O)2[C6H3(CO2)3]2·8H2O (C1), through the encapsulation of a homogeneous polyoxometalate, H5[PMo11Mn(H2O)O39] (MnP), within a metal–organic framework [Fe3O(OH)(H2O)2[C6H3(CO2)3]2·14H2O (MIL-100-Fe). In the present study, we utilized the same catalyst for the oxidation of cyclohexene (CyH), cis-cyclooctene (CyO), styrene (Sty), and geraniol (Ger) in acetonitrile, employing H2O2 as a green oxidant. Kinetic studies were carried out to investigate the influence of substrate, H2O2, catalyst concentration, reaction time, temperature, and total H2O2 decompositions on oxidation and selectivity. C1 exhibited significantly higher efficiency in catalyzing the allylic oxidation of all substrates compared to individual components MnP and MIL-100-Fe, in terms of conversion percentage, rate constants, turnover numbers (TONs), H2O2 efficiencies, and product selectivity. Under optimized conditions, C1 achieved overall conversions of 85 %, 96 %, 98 %, and 100 % for CyH, CyO, Sty, and Ger, respectively. The harmonious catalytic function of polyoxometalates (POM) and metal-organic frameworks (MOF) in C1 also reduced the auto-decomposition of H₂O₂ which resulted into higher H2O2 efficiencies. Notably, the catalyst exhibited complete recoverability and reusability without any structural changes or loss of activity.
